story:
This will be by second half marathon in a row, and this time I want to be raising as much money as possible for Macmillan Cancer Support, which is something that lies close to my heart.

Cancer is an awful disease than can not only have life threatening consequences by the sufferer but causes extreme emotional and stress for those that they hold near and dear to them; family and friends alike.

Organisations like Macmillan Cancer Support need us now more than ever - especially given the 2020 we would all wish to forget due to a certain pandemic. Many patients receiving cancer treatment have either been put on hold or cancelled whilst we grapple with COVID-19, so funding is needed to support the demand for ongoing cancer treatment. Moreover, the money raised will be contributed towards research to treat the disease, and hopefully in the future find a cure. 

I would be most grateful if all of you out there would aid me in achieving the £2500 target prior to the race.

 All donations will be welcome no matter how small or big.The training has started and hopefully I can improve on last years time - providing there are no knee injuries to grapple with. 

Thanks for reading.

Chris x

story:
David Gorman was a much respected, well-loved and highly
regarded Consultant of  Emergency Medicine, who has been taken from us far too soon. David's family and his children Matt, Sarah and Daniel have

story:
As you will all know, Bill fought ferociously hard to live as long and as well as he could, which for him meant being there to love and support his family, friends, partner, work colleagues, students and of course Parker and Lady Penelope! Two organisations in particular helped him to do this.

This page is in support of the incredible guys at Macmillan. Their brilliant helpline and information booklets are the first port in the cancer storm. Their amazing nurses are the last. I cannot imagine what the previous few months would have been like without the tireless support of Bill's incredible Super-Nurse. She quietly, efficiently and professionally accessed all the resources it was possible to access, adjusting medication until Bill was largely pain free with minimum side-effects, anticipating needs, listening attentively to his wishes and compassionately to his fears, responding to rapid changes in his condition, advocating with other professionals on his behalf (where needed with the patience of a saint!) thus accessing scans and appropriate treatments and most critically, working with a level of love and care that was truly outstanding. There aren't words to do justice to her contribution to his quality of life over the last few months.  Bill (and myself) could not have asked for better support.

story: This is the fundraising page for Warwick University Unit - St John Ambulance ! The University of Warwick First Aid Society and St John Ambulance unit work hand in hand to deliver up-to-date first aid Awareness sessions and outreach sessions in the local community. Our first aiders have supported the NHS throughout the Coronavirus pandemic by supporting in hospitals and at blood donation centres. We have volunteered almost 1800 hours of since the first lockdown began and over 2300 hours in total this year. How your donation saves lives: £4: Can give a child a 60-minute first aid lesson in school £10: Could kit out volunteers with the correct equipment to treat sick or injured people £15: Can help us keep one of our ambulances on the road serving the community for a day £25: Allows us to equip someone with the first aid skills to save a life £40: Could train a volunteer to give first aid at events like football matches and concerts £60: Can provide a volunteer with the kit they need to save a life £100: Can pay for a trainer to deliver training to a class of 32 children

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

story:
I am a huge chocolate fan. It is practically one of my five a day .. every hour!!! So this is a challenge for me therefore its a great reason to raise funds!!! 

I've known to many people who have suffered with heart problems from all over the spectrum but the biggest shock factor was losing my uncle extremely sudden. 

I've always wanted to do something for BHF but never really seen something of a challenge till now.. no chocolate for 31 days... 

I can't go 1 day without a chunk and turning into a gargoyle so this will be tough but nothing is tougher then losing loved ones so bring it on .

Any sponsor amount great or small would be appreciated and a massive incentive to face this. 

(Even my students know I love chocolate,  2 years down the line,they still remind me of my massive chocolate wrapper they found in the bin and they think my home is Cadburys World)

Much love 

Chocoholic Queen of Cadburys

story:

The British Heart foundation is a charity I have raised money for in the past, a sponsored skydive in memory of my Grandad and I have previously took part in Dechox  in memory of my Nan. This time I am giving up chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks for the month of March in memory of them both.

I’d be truly grateful for any donation you can spare, I know times are hard at the moment. This pandemic is the biggest challenge they’ve faced in the British heart foundations 60 year history. story:
Thanks so much for taking the time to visit this Just Giving page we have set up in memory of my Mum, Marie Anderson (nee Moir).

Marie entered this world on 8th February 1936, in Aberdeen and sadly departed on 20th December 2020, aged 84.

A strong, stoic, character her whole life, she held family and friendships very dear.  Always there to be relied on, never getting into a flap, she was a rock to all who loved her.

This last year was particularly tough for Marie; she faced repeated bouts of chemotherapy still with her characteristic fortitude and refusal to complain and a never-ceasing concern for those around her above herself. She in fact went into remission with this treatment and her fighting of stomach lymphoma and blood cancer. Alas a spreading brain tumour took over towards the end of 2020.

As a family we would like to celebrate Mum’s life via a charity we all feel very grateful for – Cancer Research UK.

This year, cancer has taken its toll on every member of the Anderson crew.  Stan, Marie’s husband of 62 years is currently battling a recovery from surgery for kidney cancer. Daughter Denise has had to yet again overcome breast cancer and son Graham has been diagnosed with a  blood cancer.  So we are all very vested in the remarkable treatment advancements and options that Cancer UK is driving.

As such, we are all very grateful for any donation you would like to make – both as a fitting tribute to our wonderful mum, wife – but also as a very real help to fighting this awful disease.

Stan, Denise & Graham

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Some of you may know that my amazing,hard working and inspirational grandad, Terry Mears, past away in October 2020. after being diagnosed a year prior, that He had a rare form of cancer called Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). 

MDS is a severe, chronic syndrome from which very few people successfully recover. It often progresses to AML, which is a form of leukaemia. There is no cure for MDS. An allogeneic bone marrow transplant (BMT) is the only potential cure or attempt, to slow it down for patients with MDS. 

My Gramp had his own business which he loved working every day, he loved seeing everyone’s faces and having a chat and a giggle. As well as Coming home to my Nan, and winding her up constantly! His personality and voice is what he’s most known and loved for by many. People would say they could hear him before they see him😄 he loved his cars , especially his new Range..and our crazy family so much. He had the biggest heart and the best stories. 

He would always tell me how proud of me he was, even if he would then follow off the statement with a sarcastic comment to wind me up. We had the best banter, constantly making fun of each other until one of us would give up! There are many of us, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Who each he had a special bond with, taught life lessons and made us laugh❤️

 However, The cancer slowly but surely ripped all of that away from him. Over the course of a year, he would visit the hospital multiple times a week for scheduled blood transfusions to help him stay as strong as he possibly could. He stayed in hospital multiple times as the year went on. The majority of 2020, he spent in the hospital, which as you can imagine was horrible due to covid we couldn’t visit him anymore. 

He lost his mobility and independence. This was the hardest thing for him to accept, as his mobility and independence was what enabled him to work, drive, socialise and just be him. He had to gain the strength to pretty much learn how to walk again as he had been so unwell for so long, he was too weak to walk and always in pain. This was when it really started to hit home that we’re loosing him.

The final time he went into hospital was the worst. ‘End of life’ care had begun. We put all things in place for him to be able to come home for the remainder of the time we had with him. District nurses and Marie Curie cancer nurses would visit multiple times a day to do their checks and care for him. I stayed at the house and worked from home during the day, then would stay awake all night to make sure he wasn’t in any pain or discomfort. Then to call out the nurses if he needed more pain relief etc. 

As the days went by he deteriorated extremely fast.He was home for a week fighting his absolute best to stay with us. He finally let himself go to rest on October 10,2020. Hardest and most physically/ emotionally draining week of my life. But him knowing i was by his side, day and night, his last breath is what helps me get through everything. 

I want to raise awareness of this rare cancer, Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). and thank Marie Curie nurses for everything they done for my Gramp and our family. I would love to raise some money as a Thank you and work towards a better future with NO CANCER💪

 So many of us, sadly have or will be affected by cancer in some way. Marie Curie  were amazing and I feel grateful for every nurse that came in.  If it wasn’t for them, we wouldn’t have been able to have him home with us🥺Once you donate, this page will send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate. Thankyou to anyone who donates and helps the Marie Curie charity to continue their amazing care and support.❤️

story: On March 5th 2020 we lost our lovely Lou, before the world changed - her family & friends life’s had already changed forever. Almost one year on, we still have not had opportunity to celebrate her life or give her the send off she truly deserves - as Covid restrictions literally hit as we laid her to rest of 31st March 2020. On the 24th March 2021; Lou would be celebrating her 40th birthday. This is why we want to ‘March for Lou’ and would ask anyone that wants to get involved join us too 💛 Whether you want to raise money for this or any other charity, we would love for you to join us in honouring her memory throughout the month of March. You do not need to take part every day, do as much as you can, when you can. This will be a huge challenge for me personally; (mentally & physically) there are days when I struggle to even walk around the block. Our beautiful Lou spent her last weeks under the care of Marie Curie and in thanks to them in allowing us to spend precious time with her; I am hoping to raise funds to allow them to continue in helping families tragic times. Daffodils lined the streets and roads the month Lou passed, even more so it seemed March 2020..... I can’t help but think this was her way of letting us know she was ok & showing us that her bright, vibrant energy will be with us always. 🌼💛🌼

story:
Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page.
Since the pandemic began in early 2020 we have had to cancel events and have been unable to be out and about talking to you about the work of the RNLI in and around Gateshead.
This is having a huge effect on donations which is why we are coming out to our friends, families and supporters virtually to ask for your help - we rely on donations from you, the general public and without your support we wouldn't be able to continue saving lives at sea.
The Covid-19 pandemic has brought a new risk to our volunteers that we never could have predicted or imagined but our brave and courageous crew members continue to risk their lives to save others.
We hope that you can support us by donating on our page - we look forward to seeing you soon, stay safe.




Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all Yorkshire and the North East lifeboat stations is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the pounds start to add up. Since the Covid-19 pandemic, we haven't been able to fundraise as normal to keep our lifeboats afloat. We rely on donations from the public to continue saving lives at sea - your donation to this page will help support the running of our 19 stations in Yorkshire and the North East; Amble, Berwick upon Tweed, Blyth, Bridlington, Craster, Cullercoats, Filey, Flamborough, Hartlepool, Humber, Newbiggin, Redcar, Scarborough, Seahouses, Staithes and Runswick, Sunderland, Tynemouth, Whitby and Withernsea

story:
The RNLI Grace Darling Museum commemorates the life of Victorian Britain’s greatest heroine, who risked her life to rescue nine survivors from the wrecked SS Forfarshire on 7 September 1838

The Grace Darling Museum guides you through Grace’s upbringing and life in the lighthouse, the events of the rescue that propelled her into the limelight and her status as a national heroine. Learn about Grace’s story through her personal items, including letters, family portraits and the famous coble used in the rescue. And find yourself transported back to 1838 with our audio-visual tools and a stunning model of the Longstone lighthouse.  

Due to Covid-19 the museum is currently closed and we are unable to fundraise for the RNLI as normal.  

Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all Yorkshire and the North East lifeboat stations is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the pounds start to add up. Since the Covid-19 pandemic, we haven't been able to fundraise as normal to keep our lifeboats afloat. We rely on donations from you the public to continue saving lives at sea - your donation to this page will help support the running of our 19 stations in Yorkshire and the North East; Amble, Berwick upon Tweed, Blyth, Bridlington, Craster, Cullercoats, Filey, Flamborough, Hartlepool, Humber, Newbiggin, Redcar, Scarborough, Seahouses, Staithes and Runswick, Sunderland, Tynemouth, Whitby and Withernsea

story:
Hi :) I'm a teen from the UK, and have always loved the idea fundraising for charities and causes. If you could stop by and leave a donation I would be extremely grateful! 

Over lock down I've come to realise that I'm pretty comfortable with embarrassing myself, especially when it's for a good cause. I am a pretty awful singer, but I have so much fun when I do, so, I have decided that I'm going to be singing a different song every day for a year, and upload my video -aka unleash the devils call- onto Instagram.  With hope that you kind, beautiful people will donate a tiny amount of money for the children and  families who are struggling to survive in hostile, grave environments, especially as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to effect the livelihoods of the families who are already already struggling - and families who weren't struggling originally, and forcing nearly 120, 000,000 individuals into extreme poverty. 

Please check out my Instagram, where I will be posting these mortifying videos :)) :  @awfullygood365singer 

( The first video will be uploaded Jan 20th 2021 ) 

Even if no money is raised, If you can watch my videos and have a laugh, or even sing along with me, I will be more that satisfied! I ask that you PLEASE don't take these videos too seriously, I'm showing myself in my pretty raw, down to earth state :) And hey, at the end of the year - I'm bound to have improved (slightly)!

So please! Share this around, and share a bit of love, I am extremely great-full for even the smallest donations! If not, please educate yourself on the threats that face our population and planet! 

Either way, thank you so much for taking the time to visit my page, and read my story, I hope you  have - or have had - an amazing day!

pageSummaryWhat: The Cavell Team walk virtually around Europe!
story:
The Cavell Group European teams have not been able to meet in person for almost a year. We have decided to undertake a group challenge to raise a target of £1000 for Medecins Sans Frontieres / Doctors Without Borders whilst simultaneously bringing the team together virtually and keeping active throughout the lockdown.

We are walking a total of 3,470km or 4,553,806 steps (the roundtrip distance between our 4 main offices in the UK, Netherlands, Belgium, and Portugal). Each team member is contributing between 8-10K steps per day (or cycling equivalent) and we will be walking for around 6 weeks.

We hope that you will support us in this challenge!

Thanks to our participants: Matt Townend, Gail Smith, Mike Graham, Dom Black, Francisca Dinga, Yogen Vengatass, Finbarr Goode Begley, Patrick Watson, Wendy Townend, Delina Kubrom, and Elysia Trigg for their steps!

story:
Whilst we clamour for covid vaccinations, some people today have gone without water or sanitation. 

Whilst we have waited weeks for a vaccine some people have waited a lifetime for safe water and sanitation.

Where's the fairness in that?

Although we can't change the world, North West North Tyneside Primary Care Network practices are committed to make a difference not only to those in North East England but those less fortunate in the world.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.

For every vaccine we give, we hope we give the chance of clean water and safe sanitation to those less fortunate than us.

In the first four weeks of vaccinations staff have donated £8,000 of salaries to the cause.

Please help us help those less fortunate

Many Thanks


Dr James Lunn

GP Clinical Director

On Behalf of

North West North Tyneside Primary Care Network

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Thank you for supporting me to take part in Walk In Her Shoes! 

Every day thousands of women and girls, all over the world, have no choice but to walk many miles to fetch water for their families. Water that is often dirty.

Their daily routine deprives them of the chance to have an education, a job, and traps them in a cycle of poverty.

Your support can help build wells and water pumps closer to rural communities so that women and girls dont have to spend their days walking for water, and can plan for a better future.

For more information please visit www.careinternational.org.uk where their website is kept up-to-date regularly.
